Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Cracking; Recent activity on similar slopes; Recent activity on different slopes; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Widespread cracking within 20180110 HST with isolated collapsing. HS varied on N NTL slopes from 40-90cm, deepest in wind loaded locations. 20180110 HST 34 cm in the Cascade zone and held a much deeper snpk before the storm on N'ly slopes compared to Hotel Draw. 2cm 1F MFC below 20180110 HST layer of most concern. Failing on 1.5mm FC below crust.
2m ECTN 6 @ 150cm 2m ECTN 21 @ 126cm

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Moderate wind loading along ridge tops above pit location for past 24hrs. 3in of new snow reported at monarch ski area in last 24hrs. @64cm a thin visible layer, hard to identify grains/size, could be very small surface hoar. Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown; Collapsing, localized; Cracking; Recent activity on different slopes
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug on crown of avalanche found on our route. Crown was ~35 cm thick, and slid on depth hoar at 39 cm in snowpack. We classified the Ax as: SS-N-D1/R2-O. We performed an ECT (ECTN14, SC, Q1) near the crown but did not get propagation, though the Ax clearly exhibited some amount of propagation, perhaps the energy had already been released?

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Where the snowpack is shallower, such as this location, the pack is much weaker. CPST 30/100 end @ 77 cm's

Pit dug in near treeline terrain. Interesting PST results that did not match expected after performing CT and ECT. Cracking in the area was very minor and localized, extending no more than 15 cm from skis.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Cracking
Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug in isolated wind slab on leeward, abrupt convexity. Shallow facets, and boot pen. to ground, where wind hasn't deposited snow. Recent wind event seems to have stripped fetches down to the old snow or even the ground, and deposited very hard windslabs on lee slopes.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug just off ridgeline in a wind loaded area. 1 whumpf experienced later during tour in upper elevation terrain with a hard wind slab/faceted layer combo.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry
Collapsing, localized; We skied slope

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Skier's right high in Lonestar. Looking for November 27 crust/facet layer in ski compacted terrain. Dug in a windloaded area, HS 195. Average HS across Lonestar 60-80cm.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Cracking
Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Cracking; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Area has been opened to public but has seen no skier compaction due to protected location below cliffs. Did not dig to ground. Two buried weak layers collapsed easily, but slab from 132 - 126 could not hold together in extended columns. Snowpack region wide has a very high degree of spatial variability, but this pack is consistent for this aspect and elevation, in areas with little to no skier compaction.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Recent activity on similar slopes

Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
HS is 120, I just want to the scale to be 200cm so I can compare pits over time as things get deeper...
The peculiar piece on this pit was just how big (2-3mm) the facets are between the Oct crusts and the Nov (Thanksgiving) crusts. Totally junk and not inspiring. The thing is, that I bet the Thanksgiving era crusts can hold a LOT of load before failing on these grains. Naturally the hope is that: A) this is a localized snowpack structure & not widespread B) these facets begin to sinter before they ever see any real load. Lot's of talk about the DDL beginning to heal in this part of the range. We will see, but the ECT result still shows propagation and every day we seem to get a random report of activity.
Vind 8 ms
